worklogs.comment:
wesm commented on pull request #5150: ARROW-6227: [Python] Apply from_pandas option in pyarrow.array consistently across types
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5150
 
 
   Many sequence converters were not using the `from_pandas` option in `pyarrow.array` (which is `False` by default), so `NaN` and other pandas null sentinel values were being silently converted to Arrow null. For example as in the original report `pyarrow.array(['string', np.nan])` would return an array with 1 null. This is definitely not good.
   
   I made an effort to apply this consistently where it wasn't being applied and add appropriate unit tests. 
   
   Some notes:
   
   * We don't consistently raise TypeError or ValueError on mixed type input. For example
   
   ```
   In [4]: pa.array(['string', np.nan])
   TypeError
   In [7]: pa.array([0, np.nan], type=pa.time32('s')) 
   ValueError
   ```
   
   * We weren't handling integer inputs for time32/time64 types. That's fixed and tested in passing here (though not for correctness...) 
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

jorisvandenbossche commented on pull request #5150: ARROW-6227: [Python] Apply from_pandas option in pyarrow.array consistently across types
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5150#discussion_r316066395
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/tests/test_array.py
 ##########
 @@ -1046,6 +1046,21 @@ def test_array_conversions_no_sentinel_values():
     assert arr3.null_count == 0
 
 
+def test_binary_string_pandas_null_sentinels():
+    def _check_case(ty):
+        with pytest.raises(TypeError):
+            # NaN is a float by default
+            pa.array(['string', np.nan], type=ty)
+
+        arr = pa.array(['string', np.nan], type=ty, from_pandas=True)
+        expected = pa.array(['string', None], type=ty)
+        assert arr.equals(expected)
+
+    _check_case(None)
+    _check_case('binary')
+    _check_case('utf8')
+
 
 Review comment:
   It might be worth to add some additional test cases. Some things that worked on 0.14.1 (but that should fail):
   
   ```
   In [17]: pa.array([pd.Timestamp("2012"), np.nan]) 
   Out[17]: 
   <pyarrow.lib.TimestampArray object at 0x7febe0090888>
   [
     2012-01-01 00:00:00.000000,
     null
   ]
   
   In [19]: import datetime 
   
   In [20]: pa.array([datetime.date(2012, 1, 1), np.nan]) 
   Out[20]: 
   <pyarrow.lib.Date32Array object at 0x7febe00700f8>
   [
     2012-01-01,
     null
   ]
   
   In [26]: pa.array([False, True, np.nan]) 
   Out[26]: 
   <pyarrow.lib.BooleanArray object at 0x7febe00a5e08>
   [
     false,
     true,
     null
   ]
   ```
   
   The above now all work with this branch (and struct was already working).
   
   One thing I noticed that does not yet work correctly is pd.NaT for the datetime case:
   
   ```
   In [6]: pa.array([pd.Timestamp("2012-01-01"), pd.NaT])                                                                                                                                                             
   Out[6]: 
   <pyarrow.lib.TimestampArray object at 0x7f46c8368780>
   [
     2012-01-01 00:00:00.000000,
     0001-01-01 00:00:00.000000
   ]
   ```
   
   where `pd.NaT` is converted to "0001-01-01", which is strange, as that does not even correspond with the integer value of pd.NaT. I opened https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6305 for this.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

   There's a failure in `arrow-python-test`, will fix
   
   ```
   [ RUN      ] DecimalTest.TestNoneAndNaN
   ..\src\arrow\python\python_test.cc(430): error: Failed
   'ConvertPySequence(list, {}, &arr)' failed with Type error: int or Decimal object expected, got float
   ```
   
   Frankly not sure we need this test. I'll expand the Python unit test I added to include decimals

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description: pa.array() by default regards np.nan as float value and fails on pa.array([np.nan, 'string']). It should also fail on pa.array(['string', np.nan]) instead of coercing it to null value.
fields.summary: [Python] pyarrow.array() shouldn't coerce np.nan to string
